oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Interviews Conway Twitty
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Conway Twitty (performer) for Nashville's WSM. Recording is from April 22, 1982.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Conway Twitty
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Conway Twitty and Ralph Emery discuss Dick Clark and Roone Arledge before performing interview -- (01:51) Emery introduces Twitty and both list the famous people living in Hendersonville -- (02:55) Emery and Twitty discuss Twitty's Twitty City and Twitty discusses his radio show on KFFA -- (04:28) Emery invites Twitty to discuss how he acquired a copy of his old radio show -- (05:04) The success of 'It's Only Make Believe' is reflected on by Twitty -- (06:27) Emery introduces Twitty to talk about Twitty City and Barbara Mandrell's upcoming complex -- (07:39) Emery discusses how he and Twitty used to argue about "You've Never Been This Far Before" -- (10:04) Emery and Twitty reflect on how one would get to Twitty City from the Midwest -- (13:33) "I'd Love to Lay You Down" is discussed based on its polarizing nature -- (14:22) Twitty discusses his relationship with the Statler Brothers and how he wishes to include them on his television special -- (15:30) Emery and Twitty reflect on what Twitty's surveys said people wished to see when they visit Nashville -- (17:33) Emery expresses his appreciation for Twitty and both say goodbye -- (18:08) Emery and Twitty discuss the name of Twitty City and its impending opening -- (19:30) Emery and Twitty discuss how Twitty had recently moved -- (21:13) "Hello Darlin" and "If You Were Mine to Lose" are reflected on by Twitty -- (22:13) Emery has Twitty recall the five most requested songs of his -- (22:54) Emery and Twitty discuss Twitty's six zones of his showcase -- (25:02) Emery and Twitty discuss how Twitty wrote "As Soon As I Hang Up the Phone" -- (26:36) T. G. Sheppard is praised by Twitty -- (27:25) Twitty and Emery discuss Twitty's father's river-boat career -- (30:01) Eddie Raven discussed -- (30:27) Twitty and Emery joke about when Crystal Gayle performed with him on "Don't Cry Joni" -- (31:20) Emery has Twitty discuss Twitty City's operation schedule -- (32:08) Emery says his goodbyes with Twitty -- (32:50) Emery and Twitty discuss the salesmanship they performed
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Twitty, Conway;
